questions.question: Non-contrast CT brain: History of hypertension and sudden onset of left facial droop. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points:
The image shows a large area of high density in the right frontal lobe due to acute bleeding. The CT was non-contrast and so this can’t be an enhancing mass.
Its position indicates it is in the brain (intra-axial) rather than extra-axial, so subarachnoid and subdural haemorrhage are ruled out.
The focus of high density in the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle is the calcified choroid plexus, a normal finding.

questions.question: Poor historian with increasing confusion over several weeks. What does the image show?
options: Brain atrophy without evidence of haemorrhage
questions.learning_points:
The left-sided subdural collection is easy to see. There is also a thin subdural collection on the right.
If you see one abnormality, don’t forget to continue viewing the scan systematically.

questions.question: Post contrast CT brain: Patient with colon cancer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.learning_points:
In a patient with a known malignancy a mass in the brain is most likely due to metastatic disease. Two primary lesions occurring simultaneously, benign or malignant, is rare.
The image shows enhancement of normal vessels as well as the enhancing masses.
There is no evidence of subarachnoid haemorrhage.

questions.question: Non-contrast CT brain: Anticoagulated patient with sudden onset of confusion and right hemiparesis. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points: High density material fills the left lateral ventricle. This is blood which extended from an intracerebral haemorrhage of the adjacent peri-ventricular white matter.

questions.question: What does the image show?
options: Poor quality scan of the brain which should be repeated
questions.learning_points:
This CT brain image on bone window settings shows a depressed skull fracture.
Remember to look at both the brain windows and the bone windows on all CT images of the brain.

questions.question: Non-contrast CT Brain: Sudden onset severe headache. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points:
Increased density material seen in the subarachnoid space indicates acute haemorrhage.
Although subarachnoid bleeding can extend into the ventricles, the ventricles do not contain blood in this image.

questions.question: Alcoholic found unconscious. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points: This image shows lentiform increased density material indicating acute blood in the extra-axial space (not in the brain). These are the typical appearances of an extradural haematoma.

questions.question: 2 CT brain images, pre and post-contrast: Patient with worsening headache. Which finding is NOT present?
questions.learning_points:
A large mass in the left cerebral hemisphere is causing mass effect with effacement of the sulci and left lateral ventricle (asterisk).
Low density surrounding the mass indicates vasogenic oedema of white matter.
The mass enhances peripherally but not centrally. The central portion of the mass is avascular due to cell necrosis.
Note:Abscess is a differential diagnosis

questions.question: 2 CT brain images, brain and bone window settings:  What do these images show?
options: Abnormal brain not compatible with life
questions.learning_points:
This elderly patient presented with confusion and he could not co-operate with instructions to keep still in the CT scanner.
The images have been acquired while the patient is shaking his head. Image quality is non-diagnostic.
A repeat scan later showed no acute abnormality. The confusion was due to a urinary infection, a much more common cause of confusion in elderly patients than intracranial pathology.

questions.question: 2 CT brain images, pre and post-contrast: Patient with worsening postural headache and cerebellar signs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.learning_points:
These are typical appearances of a meningioma.
This enhancing mass arises from the dura mater; in this case from the tentorium cerebelli, a sheet of dura mater which separates the posterior fossa structures from the rest of the brain.
The mass compresses the adjacent cerebellum.
